questions.text: A 35-year-old Female patient presented to the OPD with severe pain during defecation and with complaints of “blood streaking the stools''. P/R examination showed severe anal spasm.  What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fissure-in-ano

 

Option D:

 

The clinical features of fissure-in-ano are mainly pain while defecating, blood streaking the stools and constipation.

 

Fissure-in-ano: This is characterized by severe pain during defecation (often described as passing glass or a knife cutting), blood on the toilet paper, and can be associated with anal spasm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hemorrhoids: Hemorrhoids may cause painless bleeding unless thrombosed or prolapsed.

 

Option B. Perianal abscess: A perianal abscess would present with severe, constant pain, erythema, and swelling near the anus, and potentially fever, rather than pain specifically during defecation.

 

Option C. Fistula-in-ano: Fistula-in-ano usually presents with chronic discharge and may cause discomfort but not the acute, severe pain during defecation characteristic of an anal fissure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presentation of severe pain during defecation, anal spasm, and blood streaking on toilet paper is typical of an anal fissure. Treatment options include conservative measures such as increased dietary fiber, stool softeners, topical anesthetics, and vasodilators like nitroglycerin ointment. In refractory cases, lateral internal sphincterotomy or botulinum toxin injection may be required.

 

  • Although superficial, acute anal fissures are characterized by severe anal pain during defecation (‘passing glass’ or ‘a knife cutting’), which usually resolves only to recur at the next evacuation. Frequently a trace of fresh blood is noticed on tissue paper after wiping.
  • Chronic fissures are characterized by a hypertrophied anal papilla internally and a sentinel tag externally.
  • Treatment: Conservative management should result in the healing of almost all acute and the majority of chronic fissures. Emphasis must be placed on the normalization of bowel habits. The addition of fiber to the diet to bulk up the stool, stool softeners, and adequate water intake are simple and helpful measures. Warm baths and topical local anesthetic agents relieve pain.
  • Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) (0.2% applied two or three times per day to the anal margin) is a nitric oxide donor while diltiazem (2% applied twice daily) is a calcium channel antagonist. Botulinum toxin (10–100 units) injected into the internal sphincter reduces anal canal pressure.
  • Lateral internal sphincterotomy: The internal sphincter is divided away from the fissure itself – usually either in the right or the left lateral positions. Healing rates are in the range of 85%, but there is also a significant risk of altered continence
  • An anal advancement flap to cover the anal fissure should be considered in those with an increased risk of altered continence following lateral internal sphincterotomy, especially in postpartum women and those with normal or low resting anal pressures.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1428

questions.text: A newborn is found to have a pathology for which an imaging is done as below. Which of the following additional anomalies is least likely to be associated with this condition, considering the common associations of the pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Wilms tumor

 

Option C:

 

The image is an invertogram done for ARM. ARM is associated with VACTER-L syndrome.

Insults acting during gastrulation – when cells are told what to do and where to go – may cause multiple anomalies, e.g., VACTERL syndrome (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal, renal and limb anomalies) and CHARGE syndrome (coloboma eye, heart defects, choanal atresia, growth retardation, genital anomalies and ear anomalies).

 

Wilms' tumor: While renal anomalies are part of the VACTERL association, Wilms' tumor specifically is not typically included and is not usually a concurrent finding at birth with ARM. Rather, renal agenesis is seen in VACTER-L.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. T-E fistula: Tracheoesophageal fistula is part of the VACTERL association, which includes vertebral defects, anorectal malformations, cardiac defects, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal anomalies, and limb abnormalities.

 

Option B. Missing forearm bones: Limb anomalies, such as missing bones, are also part of the VACTERL association and could coexist with ARM.

 

Option D. Hemi-vertebrae: Vertebral anomalies, such as hemi-vertebrae, are part of the spectrum of abnormalities that may present with ARM as part of the VACTERL association.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anorectal malformation in a newborn is commonly associated with other anomalies as part of the VACTERL association, including tracheoesophageal fistula, limb anomalies like missing bones, and vertebral anomalies such as hemi-vertebrae. Wilms' tumor, however, is not commonly a part of this association.Top of Form

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 263

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with something coming out per anus (SCOPA) and splash in the pan type of blood in stools. On examination, the mass remains outside and has crossed the anal verge but can be manually reduced. Which is the grade of the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hemorrhoids are symptomatic enlargements of the internal haemorrhoidal venous plexus (Greek: haima = blood, rhoos = flowing; synonym: piles, Latin: pila = a ball). Internal hemorrhoids characteristically lie in the 3, 7, and 11 o’clock positions (with the patient in the lithotomy position)

  • The internal haemorrhoidal plexus constitutes the submucosal component of the anal cushions that are important in sealing the anal canal. Man’s upright posture, the absence of valves in the portal venous system and raised abdominal pressure due to pregnancy or particularly through straining during defecation contribute to venous plexus engorgement and development of varicosities. Shearing forces lead to mucosal trauma (bleeding) and caudal displacement of the anal cushions (prolapse).

 

Four degrees of hemorrhoids:

  • First degree - Bleed only, no prolapse

  • Second degree - Prolapse but reduce spontaneously

  • Third degree - Prolapse but have to be manually reduced

  • Fourth degree - Permanently prolapsed

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grade III internal hemorrhoids are characterized by prolapse during straining or defecation that can be manually reduced, distinguishing them from Grade IV, which are irreducible.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1430

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with bleeding during defecation and straining. Examination reveals pile mass which appears on straining, at 7 and 11 O'clock, and reduces spontaneously. Preferred treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barron’s Banding

 

Option A:

 

Barron’s Banding: This is the correct choice for initial treatment in this scenario. Rubber band ligation, also known as Barron's banding, is effective for first and second-degree hemorrhoids that are reducible. It involves placing a tight elastic band at the base of the hemorrhoid to cut off blood supply, causing the hemorrhoid to shrivel and detach.

 

This is a case of second degree hemorrhoids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy: This surgical procedure is generally reserved for more severe hemorrhoids, typically prolapsed or third-degree hemorrhoids that do not respond to other treatments.

 

Option C. Milligan Morgan procedure: This is an open surgical technique for hemorrhoidectomy, usually indicated for third and fourth-degree hemorrhoids, or second-degree hemorrhoids that have not responded to non-operative treatments.

 

Option D. Sitz bath: While a Sitz bath can relieve symptoms, it is not a definitive treatment for hemorrhoids that are not responsive to conservative management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For reducible first and second-degree internal hemorrhoids that are not responsive to conservative measures, Barron’s Banding is an effective initial treatment before considering surgical options.

 

  • In patients with first or second-degree internal haemorrhoids whose symptoms are not improved by conservative measures, injection sclerotherapy with submucosal injection of 5% phenol in arachis oil or almond oil may be used.
  • It is important to inject about 3-5 mL of sclerosant into the apex of the pedicle and not into the haemorrhoid itself using a disposable needle and syringe. Injections placed too deeply can have serious consequences, including prostatitis and pelvic sepsis.
  • For this reason, haemorrhoidal injection has largely been superseded by rubber band ligation. The Barron’s bander is a commonly available device used to slip tight elastic bands onto the base of the pedicle of each hemorrhoid. The band must be applied above the dentate line as below can cause intense pain. The bands cause ischaemic necrosis of the piles, which slough off within 10 days; this may be associated with bleeding, about which the patient must be warned

 

The indications for haemorrhoidectomy include:    

           

  • Third and fourth-degree haemorrhoids                                                             
  • Second-degree hemorrhoids that have not been cured by on-operative treatments;
  • ‘Mixed’ hemorrhoids when the external hemorrhoid is well defined;
  • Bleeding causing anaemia.

 

This can be done by:

  • Open technique of Milligan Morgan
  • Closed technique of Ferguson
  • Stapled technique of Longo

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1431-32

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of perianal discomfort and purulent discharge. On physical examination, there is induration in the perianal region, suggestive of a chronic fistula-in-ano. No external openings are visible. The surgical team is considering the best imaging modality to delineate the anatomy of the suspected fistulous tract and any potential secondary extensions before proceeding with surgery. What is the investigation of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MRI

 

Option A:

 

MRI is the gold standard for imaging in cases of fistula-in-ano due to its excellent soft tissue contrast, which allows for precise visualization of the fistulous tract. The Short Tau Inversion Recovery (STIR) sequence can be particularly helpful by highlighting areas of inflammation without the need for contrast material. MRI is superior for identifying any secondary extensions or abscesses that may not be apparent during surgery, which is critical for treatment planning and can help prevent recurrence of the condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. CECT abdomen pelvis can be helpful in certain abdominal pathologies but is less sensitive than MRI for the soft tissue detail needed in anal fistulae.

 

Option C. Proctoscopy is a direct visualization technique that can be useful for assessing the internal orifice and local inflammation but does not provide information about the full extent of the fistula tract.

 

Option D. Sigmoidoscopy is utilized to visualize the sigmoid colon and may be useful in excluding other colonic pathologies but not as first-line imaging for a fistula-in-ano.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating fistula-in-ano due to its ability to delineate the anatomy of the fistulous tract and identify any secondary extensions, which is essential for effective surgical management.

 

  • Fistulography and computed tomography (CT) are useful if an extra-sphincteric fistula is suspected.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1438

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with recurrent perianal abscesses and purulent drainage noted at the 6 o'clock position in relation to the anus. He reports intermittent discomfort and swelling in the perianal region that seems to temporarily improve with antibiotics but has recurred several times. On examination, an external opening is noted in the perianal skin with induration suggestive of a chronic fistulous tract. The patient expresses his desire for a definitive treatment that would minimize the risk of incontinence. Which of the following is not a treatment option for fistula in ano?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Internal sphincterotomy

 

Option D:

 

Internal sphincterotomy: Although it may be part of the treatment for chronic anal fissures, it is not typically recommended for fistulas because the procedure involves cutting a portion of the internal sphincter muscle, which can lead to incontinence, particularly if the fistula involves a significant portion of the sphincter complex.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cutting setons: This involves placing a seton (thread or wire) to gradually cut through the fistulous tract over time, allowing for healing from the inside out. It is used for complex or high fistulas to avoid significant sphincter damage in one operation.

 

Option B. LIFT: A minimally invasive technique that aims to preserve sphincter function. The intersphincteric fistula tract is ligated and divided at the intersphincteric plane without disturbing the sphincter muscles.

 

Option C. VAAFT: This endoscopic technique allows the surgeon to see inside the fistula tract and to cauterize or excise the tract with minimal disruption to the sphincter muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Internal sphincterotomy is not generally recommended for treating trans-sphincteric fistulas but for acute fissure in ano. The correct management would involve methods that aim to preserve sphincter integrity while adequately addressing the fistula.

 

Surgery for fistula-in-ano:

 

  • Fistulotomy involves division of all structures lying between the external and internal openings. It is therefore applied mainly to intersphincteric fistula and trans-sphincteric fistulae involving less than 30% of the external sphincter (but not anterior fistulae in women)
  • Fistulectomy involves coring out of the fistula, usually by diathermy cautery; it allows a better definition of fistula anatomy than fistulotomy, especially the level at which the track crosses the sphincters and the presence of secondary extensions.
  • Loose setons are tied such that there is no tension upon the encircled tissue; there is no intent to cut the tissue. A variety of materials have been used but the seton should be non-absorbable, non-degenerative, and comfortable. Tight or cutting setons are placed with the intention of cutting through the enclosed muscle. Loose setons are also used for long-term palliation to avoid septic and painful exacerbations by establishing effective drainage
  • Cutting setons aim to achieve the high fistula eradication rates associated with fistulotomy but without the degree of functional impairment endowed by division of the sphincters at a single stage.
  • LIFT (Ligation of inter-sphincteric fistula tract):

 

LIFT involves disconnection of the internal opening from the fistula tract at the level of the inter-sphincteric plane and removal of the residual infected glands without dividing any part of the sphincter complex. The tract is then ligated and divided, the internal part is removed and the external part of the track is curetted and drained.

 

  • VAAFT (Video-assisted anal fistula tract excision):

 

The procedure involves the use of a special endoscope equipped with a camera and a laser fiber to visualize and remove the fistula tract while preserving the sphincter muscles. The advantage of VAAFT is that it offers a high success rate, minimal pain, and faster recovery compared to traditional surgical techniques.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1440

questions.text: Identify the structure numbered 11 in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal sphincter

 

Option B:

 

Part 11 signifies the internal anal sphincter. The internal sphincter is the thickened (2–5 mm) distal continuation of the circular muscle layer of the rectum. This sphincter is involuntary. Damage to this sphincter doesn’t cause faecal incontinence.

 

Internal sphincter is the thickened continuation of the circular muscle layer of the rectum and serves as an involuntary control of defecation.

 

1 - Levator ani muscle (iliococcygeus muscle)

2 - Levator ani muscle (puborectalis muscle)

3–5 - External anal sphincter (deep, superficial, subcutaneous)

6 - Inferior haemorrhoidal plexus

7 - Perianal skin

8 - Anoderm

9 - Anal columns and crypts

10 - Conjoined longitudinal muscle (Corrugator ani muscle)

11 - Internal anal sphincter

12 - Superior haemorrhoidal plexus

13 - Anorectal junction

14 - Circular rectal muscle layer

15 - Longitudinal rectal muscle

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Levator ani includes the iliococcygeus and puborectalis muscles, which form part of the pelvic floor and contribute to the maintenance of fecal continence by providing structural support to the rectum and anal canal.

 

Option C. External sphincter consists of the deep, superficial, and subcutaneous parts and is under voluntary control.

 

Option D. Circular muscle of rectum is part of the muscular structure of the rectum, which is distinct from the internal anal sphincter

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal anal sphincter is labeled as number 11 in anatomical diagrams of the anal canal and is identified as a thickened distal continuation of the circular muscle layer of the rectum, functioning involuntarily.

 

Ref:  Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg. 1418

choices.text: Internal sphincter injury doesn’t lead to fecal incontinence if external sphincter is intact
Internal sphincter is a continuation of the circular muscle coat of the rectum
Anal canal is derived entirely from proctodaeum
Part of the anus above the dentate line lacks sensations

questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anal canal is derived entirely from proctodaeum

 

Option C:

 

  • Anal canal is derived from cloaca (above dentate line) and proctodaeum (below dentate line).

 

Option C is incorrect. The anal canal has dual embryonic origins; the portion above the dentate line is derived from the endoderm (cloaca), while the area below is from the ectoderm (proctodeum).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. is correct: The internal sphincter, made up of smooth muscle, contributes to some amount continence at rest. Injury to this sphincter doesn’t indeed lead to fecal incontinence, if external sphincter is intact.

 

Option B. is correct: The internal sphincter is the thickened (2–5 mm) distal continuation of the circular muscle layer of the rectum.

 

Option D. is correct: The part of the anus above the dentate line lacks sensations such as pain and temperature because it is innervated by visceral sensory fibers, unlike the area below the dentate line, which has somatic innervation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorrect statement is that the anal canal is not entirely derived from the proctodeum; it has a dual embryonic origin, with the part above the dentate line being endodermal and the part below being ectodermal.

 

  • The internal sphincter is the thickened (2–5 mm) distal continuation of the circular muscle layer of the rectum. This involuntary muscle commences where the rectum passes through the pelvic diaphragm and ends above the anal orifice, its lower border palpable at the inter-sphincteric groove

  • The external sphincter forms the bulk of the anal sphincter complex. It is a single muscle (Goligher), which is variably divided by lateral extensions from the longitudinal muscle layer. Some of the fibers are attached to the coccyx posteriorly, whereas anteriorly they fuse with the perineal muscles. Being a somatic voluntary muscle, the external sphincter is red in color.

  • The row of alternating columns and crypts gives a serrated appearance known as the dentate line, which is considered to be the embryological junction between the endodermal and ectodermal parts of the anal canal (the proctodaeum).

  • Below the dentate line, the anoderm is lined by non-keratinised stratified squamous epithelium that is devoid of glands and hair but richly innervated by somatic sensory nerve endings

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1418

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the use of the given instrument is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anal fissure

 

Option C:

 

The instrument given in the above image is a proctoscope.

 

Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately in acute anal fissure, but reserved for later, when the symptoms resolve or the patient is in the operating room under anesthesia.

 

Anal fissure: Proctoscopy is generally contraindicated in the acute setting of an anal fissure due to the severe pain it can cause. It is deferred until the patient is anesthetized or the acute episode has resolved.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Haemorrhoids: A proctoscope can be used to evaluate and treat hemorrhoids. It allows for the visualization of the anal canal and can assist in procedures such as rubber band ligation.

 

Option B. Anal canal biopsy: The proctoscope is an appropriate tool for visualizing the anal canal to obtain biopsy samples from suspicious areas within the canal.

 

Option D. Rectal polyp: Proctoscopy can be used to visualize and potentially remove polyps within the rectum, especially those close to the anal canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of a proctoscope is contraindicated in the presence of an acute anal fissure due to the severe pain it may cause during the examination.

choices.text: Imperforate anus is a type of Low Ano-rectal malformation (ARM)
High ARMs may result in the formulation of a persistent cloaca in females
In boys, a recto-vesical fistula is the most common type
Imperforate anus is treated by anoplasty

questions.text: A newborn male has failed to pass meconium since birth and presents with the absence of a normal anal opening. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) In boys, a recto-vesical fistula is the most common type

 

Option C:

 

Recto-vesical fistulas are not common in males with low ARM; instead, recto-urethral fistulas are more common in males with high ARMs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Imperforate anus is indeed a type of low ARM, where there is an anal membrane or anal stenosis.

 

Option B. High ARMs in females can lead to a persistent cloaca, which is a condition where the rectum, vagina, and urethra converge into a single common channel.

 

Option D: Anoplasty is a surgical procedure used to create an anal opening and is the appropriate treatment for imperforate anus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorrect statement regarding anorectal malformations in newborns is that recto-vesical fistulas are common in males. Instead, males with high ARM more commonly have recto-urethral fistulas.

 

According to Wingspread, ARMs are classified into: 

  1. Low ARMS:
  • Imperforate anus
  • Under fusion: anal membrane
  • Anal stenosis
  1. High ARMs:
  • Rectal atresia with recto-urethral (bulbar) fistula (males)
  • Rectal atresia with recto-vestibular fistula (females)

 

Imperforate anus is treated by anoplasty whereas high ARMSs are treated by ano-rectoplasty.

 

In boys, a divided proximal sigmoid colostomy allows feeding. Repair of prostatic and bladder neck fistulae may be approached with a combined laparoscopic and perineal approach, whereas prostatic and bulbar urethral fistulae can both be approached in a posterior sagittal ano-rectoplasty (PSARP). The stoma is closed at a third stage.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 289

choices.text: Age of presentation is at birth.
Interdigital pilonidal sinus is an occupational disease of hairdressers.
Intermittent pain, swelling and discharge at the base of the spine is often seen.
Hair follicles are rarely present in the walls of the sinus.

questions.text: What about the following about the condition shown below is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age of presentation is at birth

 

Option A:

 

  • The age of the appearance of a pilonidal sinus is older than expected of a congenital lesion. It is usually seen in teenagers.

 

Pilonidal sinus is not typically present at birth. It usually manifests after puberty, often related to changes during adolescence and increased hair growth

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. An interdigital pilonidal sinus can be an occupational disease in hairdressers, caused by chronic embedding of hair fragments between the fingers.

 

Option C. Intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine are characteristic symptoms of a pilonidal sinus due to infection and abscess formation.

 

Option D. Hair follicles themselves are not commonly found in the walls of a pilonidal sinus. The condition is associated with ingrown hairs that have created a foreign body reaction in the subcutaneous tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pilonidal sinus disease typically does not present at birth; it usually occurs after puberty and is more common in young adult males. The disease is characterized by intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine and can be associated with occupational risks in hairdressers. Hair follicles are not commonly found in the walls of the sinus.

 

  • It is thought that the combination of buttock friction and shearing forces in that area allows shedding hair or broken hairs that have collected there to drill through the midline skin, or infection in relation to a hair follicle allows hair to enter the skin by the suction created by movement of the buttocks, so creating a subcutaneous, chronically infected, midline track.                                                                     
  • The condition is seen much more frequently in men than in women, usually after puberty and before the fourth decade of life. Patients complain of intermittent pain, swelling and discharge at the base of the spine. There is often a history of repeated abscesses that have burst spontaneously.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1423

questions.text: Identify the procedure done for the pilonidal sinus.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bascom’s procedure

 

Option A:

 

Bascom’s procedure involves an incision lateral to the midline to gain access to the sinus cavity, which is rid of hair and granulation tissue, and excision and closure of the midline pits. The lateral wound is left open to heal secondarily.

 

Bascom’s procedure: This is an appropriate procedure for pilonidal sinus, involving an incision lateral to the midline. It is designed to minimize recurrence by excising the sinus tract and midline pits and leaving the lateral wound to heal secondarily.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Karydakis flap: This technique involves asymmetrical excision of the sinus with the creation of a flap to move the natal cleft away from the midline, reducing the risk of recurrence.

 

Option C. Limberg flap: This procedure utilizes a rhomboid-shaped flap and is also used for pilonidal sinus treatment. It transposes tissue to fill the defect created by the excision of the sinus.

 

Option D. Chimeric flap: A chimeric flap is not a standard procedure for pilonidal sinus and involves using tissue from more than one source area or vascular supply, typically used in more complex reconstructive surgeries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bascom’s procedure is a surgical technique used for pilonidal sinus that involves lateral incision and excision of the tract, with the aim of minimizing recurrence and leaving the wound to heal secondarily.

 

 

1A and 1B- Karydakis

2A and 2B- Limberg flap

 

Re: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1423-24

choices.text: Bleeding is associated with severe pain
Portal pyemia is a rare complication
Sigmoidoscopy is preferred in the elderly as an investigation of choice

questions.text: In patients diagnosed with internal hemorrhoids, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bleeding is associated with severe pain

 

Option B:

 

The bleeding is usually painless, although it may be associated with pruritus, as hemorrhoids occur above the dentate line (insensitive).

 

Complications:

  • Strangulation and thrombosis

  • Ulceration

  • Gangrene

  • Portal pyaemia (Option C)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Bleeding is the earliest symptom. The nature of the bleeding is characteristically separate from the motion and is seen either on the paper on wiping or as a fresh splash in the pan. The bleeding is rarely sufficient to cause anemia and other causes should be excluded.

 

Investigations: Proctoscopy, although sigmoidoscopy is preferred in the elderly to rule out rectosigmoid malignancy (Option D)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The bleeding associated with internal hemorrhoids is typically painless because it originates from above the dentate line, an area with a lesser density of pain-sensing nerves.Top of 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1430

questions.text: Which of these is the most common complication following hemorrhoidectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urinary retention

 

Explanation:

 

Urinary retention is the most common complication following hemorrhoidectomy from the given options (after reactionary hemorrhage). It is seen in up to 15-30% of the patients.

 

Other complications:

• Fecal incontinence (2%)

• Infection (1 %)

• Delayed hemorrhage (1%)

• Stricture (1%)

 

Patients typically recover quickly and can return to work within 1 to 2 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urinary retention is the most frequently reported complication following hemorrhoidectomy, occurring in up to 30% of patients. Management includes catheterization and addressing pain control to facilitate bladder function.

 

Complications of hemorrhoidectomy (Sabiston 21st ed Pg 1406):

1. Reactionary hemorrhage (1-2%) (Overall MC)

2. Acute urinary retention (1-15%)

3. Pelvic sepsis (Life threatening)

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1434

choices.text: Classification of types of perianal abscess
Site of incision and drainage of perianal abscess
Classification of anatomical types of fistula-in-ano
Prediction of course of tract in fistula-in-ano

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent perianal discharge and discomfort. Physical examination reveals an external opening of a fistulous tract located on the posterior aspect near the anus. Goodsall’s rule applies to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prediction of course of tract in fistula-in-ano

 

Option D:

 

Prediction of course of tract in fistula-in-ano: Goodsall’s rule predicts the likely course and internal opening of a fistula based on the position of the external opening.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Classification of types of perianal abscess: Goodsall’s rule does not apply to abscess classification; it is specific to fistulous tracts.

 

Option B. Site of incision and drainage of perianal abscess: While important for abscess management, Goodsall’s rule is not used to determine the incision site.

 

Option C. Classification of anatomical types of fistula-in-ano: Anatomical classification, such as intersphincteric or trans-sphincteric types, is not determined by Goodsall’s rule. That is given by Park’s classification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Goodsall’s rule predicts the direction and internal opening of an anal fistulous tract. It states that if the external opening is anterior to an imaginary transverse anal line within 3 cm of the anus, the internal opening is likely to be in the direct path, anteriorly. If the external opening is posterior to this line or greater than 3 cm from the anus, the tract usually curves to open in the midline posteriorly. This rule helps to guide surgical planning and can affect the surgical approach and technique used.

 

 

Goodsall’s rule used to indicate the likely position of the internal opening according to the position of the external opening (Predicts the direction of the fistulous tract and the internal opening)

 

According to Goodsall’s rule:

 

  1. External opening: Anterior within 3 cm, internal opening will also be anterior in the same line.
  2. External opening is posterior, internal opening will also be posterior but in midline (6 o clock).
  3. Anterior opening > 3cm, then internal opening will be posterior (6 o clock) with a curved tract.

 

Anatomical types of fistula-in-ano are given by Park’s classification:

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of chronic anal pain and recurrent perianal infections presents to the clinic. Physical examination reveals an external opening near the anal margin. A diagnosis of fistula-in-ano is considered. Which of the following types of fistula-in-ano is the least common?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extra sphincteric

 

Explanation

 

Park’s classification of fistula of ano

 

Low fistulae:

Type 1: Inter-sphincteric: 45%

Type 2: Trans-sphincteric: 40%

 

High fistulae:

Type 3: Supra sphincteric: 10%

Type 4: Extra sphincteric: 5%

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extra sphincteric fistula-in-ano is the least common type, characterized by a tract that originates from the rectal wall, crosses the levator ani muscle, and is commonly associated with systemic disease or trauma.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, pg 1436-1437

questions.text: A 45 years old male presents to the clinic with a history of discharge from the anal region for the past 2 weeks. He underwent drainage of the ischiorectal abscess 2 months back. Clinical examination and imaging reveal the presence of a supra-sphincteric perianal fistula. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seton's technique

 

Option A:

 

Seton's technique is used in the management of high lying anal fistula.

A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis.

Fistulectomy can be used only if the fistula is low enough to allow safe fistulectomy.

 

Insertion of a draining seton: This is the correct answer. Seton's technique involves placing a loop of suture or rubber material through the fistula tract, which helps drain infection and promote fibrosis, making it suitable for high-lying fistulas where direct closure risks damaging the sphincter complex.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Chemoradiation therapy: The Nigro regimen is chemoradiation therapy, usually for anal carcinoma, and not indicated for fistula treatment.

 

Option C. Rectal prolapse repair: The Delorme procedure is a rectal prolapse repair technique and is not applicable for treating anal fistulas.

 

Option D. Fistula excision: Fistulectomy involves excising the fistula tract and is usually reserved for low-lying fistulas where there is less risk of compromising sphincter function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seton's technique is the preferred method for managing high-lying anal fistulas, such as supra-sphincteric fistulas, due to its ability to promote fibrosis and maintain continence while minimizing the risk of damage to the anal sphincters.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1439

choices.text: The cryptoglandular theory states an infected inter-sphincteric gland is the starting point of abscess
Ischiorectal abscess is the most common type of anorectal abscess
Palpable, tender, erythematous perianal swelling is suggestive of abscess
These abscesses are drained by cruciate incision

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about anorectal abscess?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ischiorectal abscess is the most common type of anorectal abscess

 

Option B:

 

The most common type of anorectal abscess is the perianal type (60%).

 

B and D: For perianal and ischiorectal sepsis (with an incidence of 60% and 30%, respectively), drainage is through the perineal skin. Traditionally this has been through a cruciate incision over the most fluctuant point, with excision of the skin edges to deroof the abscess

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The cryptoglandular theory of inter-sphincteric anal gland infection (Parks) holds that pus, which travels along the path of least resistance, may spread caudally to present as a perianal abscess, laterally across the external sphincter to form an ischiorectal abscess or, rarely, superiorly above the anorectal junction to form a supra levator intermuscular.

 

Option C: A perianal abscess, confined by the terminal extensions of the longitudinal muscle, is usually associated with a short (2–3 day) history of increasingly severe, well-localized pain and a palpable tender lump at the anal margin. Examination reveals an indurated hot, tender perianal swelling.

 

Educational objective:

 

Perianal abscess (60%) is the MC type followed by ischiorectal abscess (30%). They are drained under anesthesia by giving a cruciate skin incision.

 

Ref:  Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg. 1434-35.
